reviewText: I don't know what picture the other reviewers were watching when they wrote their comments.  I have it on tape and have watched it as many times as I could take it.  I give it 2 Stars for the mementos of Helen Morgan and Paul Robeson.  The rest of the picture is a typical (or worse) Hollywood hatchet job.  The musical numbers are brutally slashed to a minimum and whole scenes are telescoped down to one line. The 'epic' quality of the original has been reduced to a claustrophobic back lot weeper.  It's easy to expect the next scene to be one of Castle Frankenstein.  The relentless and unimaginative hammering quality of Whale's direction shows he was the wrong choice.  Irene Dunne, a delightful actress in other films, is here just 'ditzy' delivering the comic scenes and too mature and totally wrong for the part.  Allan Jones is a passable Ravenal but he has been better.The costuming is late 1800's with a 1930's twist.  The tacked on weepy ending (supposedly in 1927) presents a musical number that hearkens back to something that would have been old hat at the time of the beginning of the show, instead of giving Kim (the daughter) a 'flapper' number as in the original!  I have a tape of the stage production done from the Paper Mill Playhouse in the 1980's (done with the Hammerstein estate approval) and it is, to this point, the only thing I have ever seen that comes anywhere near the original. On DVD you might have the option to skip to the Morgan and Robeson songs which would be the only advantage.
summary: Show Boat 1936 ... Not A Very Good Show

reviewText: This, the original movie, is the best of any of the other versions.  Fish Gotta Swim is incomparable, as well as practically all of the songs in the show.  The ups and downs of the story with the incidence of miscegenation, drunkenness, bad talent, good talent, desertion, reconciliation, all keep the viewer entranced and I find myself glued to the screen whenever I watch it.  Fluff and depth . . . they don't make them like this anymore.
summary: Classic!

reviewText: There are a couple of famous, great songs in the opening 15 minutes of this film that hooked me in to watch the entire two-hour film a number of years ago. Since then, I haven't changed my mind that this is, by far, the best version of "Show Boat" ever.It's a shame this 1936 film is not available on DVD.  It's more than a shame; it's ridiculous.  About 10 years ago, I had the chance to trade in many of my tapes for DVDs. For some reason, I held on to this one. Good thing.Frankly,  I did not particularly care for the two leading actors voices - Irene Dunne and Allan Jones. They are just two high-pitched for my tastes. I preferred the deep voice of Paul Robeson and was pleasantly surprised how well Hatie McDaniel sang.The fun part of the film, however, wasn't the music but the story. It's pretty entertaining and a key reason for that was Charles Winniger, who keeps it alive with good humor. All the characters, except for Helen Westley's, are "good guys." and nice to follow. The story has a good mixture of drama, humor, sadness, sentimentality and song.Also, there is some nice closeup photography with some great facial expressions. Some just make you laugh right out loud.
summary: Glad I Never Traded In  My Tape
Title: N/A

reviewText: Paul Robeson as Joe is in splendid voice, although I've heard him sing the verses to "Ol' Man River" at a better pace, not so hurried.  Also, the film's poor sound quality, though not greatly harming medium-range and low solo voices, murders large choruses and high climaxes.Next-best singer is Helen Morgan, as Julie La Verne.  Her alto is just right for "Can't help lovin' dat man of mine" and "Bill."  She was a member of the Broadway original cast of Show Boat; the movie preserves a golden performance.  Another member of that original cast was Charles Winninger as Cap'n Andy.  I've seen Cap'n Andy's I've liked better (e.g., Eddie Bracken and Joe E. Brown), but Winninger's performance is appealing and his great scene, pantomiming a fight between the hero and villain of a Show Boat melodrama, is spectacular.Allan Jones as Gaylord Ravenal has a lovely, light tenor voice, which usually floats above the mud in the sound system.  Unfortunately, his songs are few and abridged.  The best are the two duets he sings with Irene Dunne as Magnolia Hawks, "Make Believe" and "You Are Love."  In both cases, by partially or completely eliminating verses and repetitions, the movie prevents the emotional buildup that is important for the impact of the song.  This is especially true for the latter duet, which should be the romantic, musical climax of the show.Irene Dunne has a pleasant soprano, not quite easy in the top notes.  Physically she seemed too large-boned for Magnolia and not young enough; some of her dancing was painfully awkward.  Speaking of dancing, the operetta's dancing duo of Ellie and Frank Schultz were ruthlessly cut.  Numbers that had time in the stage version to develop and unfold as miniature and delightful works of art were turned into exercises or samples.The movie added one or two good songs not previously used on stage.  But the many other changes, whether to insert new scenes or to cut old ones, were uniformly unfortunate.  With "Oklahoma," Hollywood managed to keep a fine, stage musical reasonably intact; I wish they had done so here.
summary: Some Fine Individual Performances -- Not a Great Show
Title: N/A

reviewText: I generally do not like to use hype words, but after repeated watching I have concluded that the 1936 version of Show Boat is a masterpiece, and I would like to explain why.First, the plot has several hidden and less hidden denunciations of racism and its absurdity, as when Julie is "accused" of being a half-black passing for white, guilty of the crime of being married to a white man! Against which, her husband Steve makes a cut in her hand and sucks some of her blood, since "according to the laws of Mississippi one single drop of Negro blood makes you a Negro", hence instantly becoming a Black in front of everybody!Then the attitude of Paul Robeson, a great American who deserves a few words. Brilliant student at Rutgers, athlete, singer and actor, succeeding in everything he tried, prevented from enjoying success because he was a Black American, he suffered persecution by the infamous "Commission for Un-American activities", presided by one senator Joseph McCarthy, with the accusation of being a communist, and had his passport withdrawn. In this movie, he carries most of the show especially with the powerful "Old Man River," but also with other songs, such as "I suits me fine," built on a 12-bar blues structure. His subdued protestation is in my opinion well visible just below his skin, as during the visit of the sheriff, and the implied consciousness is remarkably advanced for a piece of the 20's filmed in the 30's. And also, when he sings "Old Man River", there is no hint of a submissive attitude, rather a pride as if saying, why should my complexion make me any less of a human being than you?The plot contains several irresistible love stories, that of Magnolia and Gaylord, of Steve and Julie - even of Andy and his scorbutic wife - that for their convincing sincerity should not make people indifferent - even hardened surly men like this writer - and will make romantic souls weep.And, last but not least, the music. Most songs are great: the already mentioned "Old Man River", which has been reinterpreted by jazzmen in several ways - see the swinging up-tempo version by Fletcher Henderson of 1933 with the vocal by Red Allen. "Can't Help Lovin Dat Man", "Make believe we are in love", were popular songs heard, among others, in a medley by the Paul Whiteman band of 1928, with a brilliant cornet solo by the great Bix Beiderbecke (like the Henderson rendition, not in the movie: write me if you are interested). Which shows that the level of musical professionalism in the United States was far higher than that of its Viennese counterpart (Lehar, Strauss) with their boring rhythms and square musical lines. I would not be original if I said that this is certainly due, aside from the mastery of Jerome Kern, to the influence of non-Western musical traditions in America, especially Black, because, among others, Antonin Dvorak and Ernest Ansermet stated the same. In fact, there are two songs containing a 12-bar blues structure borrowed from Jazz, which testifies to the erudition of the composer. Witness also the rhythmic asymmetry of the introductory melody, often played before "Old Man River".The acting is great, in particular that of Charles Winninger as Cap'n Andy, but also that of all actors. Perhaps some criticism could be made about the tearful happy ending, which lets the overall tone go down and makes this comedy a little dated. Sure, there are some naive instants typical of a musical comedy of almost seventy years ago. But nevertheless, there are no boring moments, and I am sure that the movie can be fully appreciated and enjoyed with a contemporary vantage point.
summary: Truly a masterpiece

reviewText: The classic version finally turns up on dvd and it is a fine quality print.  Irene Dunne was born to play Magnolia and Helen Morgan gets to reprise the role she created on the stage.  If that weren't enough we also have Paul Robeson, Hattie McDaniel and AlanJones.  "Ah Still Suits Me" and "Gallivantin Around" were written for this version.  That last song may have some cringing but the movie was made in 1936 and the time of the musical had many black face numbers.  Thanks to Warner Archives for getting this version out.  It will help us forget how Kathryn Grayson tried to ruin the 1951 version but Ava Gardner saved it and even ended up having the final closeup of the movie.
summary: The Best Version At Last!

reviewText: Sadly not available yet on DVD, the classic black-and-white 1936 version of the seminal 1927 Oscar Hammerstein-Jerome Kern musical is rarely seen these days since it's been overshadowed by the far more elaborate1951 MGM color remake(which is on DVD). That's a shame since this one is like a piece of cameo jewelry from a bygone era, a sublimely entertaining piece of Americana so nave in its approach that its pervasive use of racial stereotypes comes across more as quaint than demoralizing.Directed by James Whale (the protagonist of 1998'sGods and Monstersand most famous for his 1931 classic,Frankenstein), it's a multi-generational story that starts with the Hawks family who runs a variety entertainment showboat in the 1880's. The jovial Captain Andy is the boat's impresario who is constantly goaded by his mean-spirited wife Parthy. They have a musically inclined daughter Magnolia who is best friends with the show's star, mulatto chanteuse Julie LaVerne. The local sheriff forces Julie out of the show for being half-black. Andy has Magnolia take her place just as gambler Gaylord Ravenal comes to town and becomes recruited as the show's leading man. Gaylord and Magnolia fall immediately in love, marry, move to Chicago and have a girl they named Kim. There, he gains and loses a fortune and then leaves Magnolia and Kim. Over the years, Magnolia becomes a big stage star and passes the torch to Kim.The music, of course, is unbeatable with standards, chief among them "Make Believe", "Can't Help Lovin' That Man" and "You Are Love". Even though Irene Dunne was in her late thirties when she made this film, she amazingly gets away with the first half where she plays Magnolia as an ingénue. What's more, she was the rare actress who could act and sing (quite beautifully) at the same time, even when she is required to perform in blackface in "Gallivantin' Around". Allan Jones is a fine singer as Gaylord, though not as interesting an actor especially in the second half when misfortune takes over. When they sing "You Are Love" together, it's still quite magical.What a treat to be able to see the redoubtable Paul Robeson as Joe singing "Ol' Man River" so powerfully (and filmed with an intriguing montage of woeful images), as well as legendary torch singer Helen Morgan play Julie and perform her signature song, "Bill", so touchingly. Familiar character actor Charles Winninger probably has his best role as Captain Andy, while Hattie McDaniel plays Joe's forceful wife Queenie in a performance as good as her Mammy inGone with the Wind. The film is really an intriguing mix of melodrama and great music with socially relevant observations regarding racism, alcoholism and gambling addiction.
summary: Seminal Musical Classic Well Worth Seeing Seventy Years Later
Title: N/A

reviewText: Show Boat (1936)B&W;, Directed by James WhaleBased on the musical adaption of the Ferber novel of the same name and featuring a staggering catalog of brilliantly crafted songs by Jerome Kern and Oscar Hammerstein ll.Having seen what the team of Whale and Carl Laemmle Jr can do with Horror, I had to see what they could do with "The Musical". I was not disappointed. This is indeed a benchmark in film making and in American Cinema.This is one amazing piece of film history and one of the best adaptions of an "art form" to the screen, ranking up there with things like Hustons MOULIN ROUGE. Unlike MGMs watered down technicolor remake with Ava Gardner, Whales adaption is the most faithful to both the musicalized version of the Ferber novel as well as to the novel itself.There is a lot here to both love and to be shocked by. There are scenes in this movie that are absolutely soaring. Paul Robesons version of "Old Man River" is nothing short of jaw dropping. Robesons visual and vocal performance is raw passion, plain and simple. All of Robesons scenes are something to see, this guy has amazing screen gravitas to be sure. I had to watch the "Old Man River" sequence several times to study and appreciate its technical merit as well as its entertainment value, its that good.Another good bit is a song that was added to Whales movie to expand the roles of Robeson and Hattie McDaniel, the duet "Ah Still Suits Me". Take heed, there are some extreme racial stereotypes that lead to some truely embarrasing and cringe inducing moments,(Irene Dunnes "blackface performance" for example) as well as startling scenes (like Donald Cook pulling out a knife and cutting Helen Morgans hand in an effort to keep both out of prison) that are racially charged and intense.There are also scenes that are ahead of its time regarding race and integration.Helen Morgan is beautiful and quite special. Her scene singing the song "Bill" is also a wonderful and emotional bit of entertainment. Charles Winnengers scene halfway into the movie is nothing short of brilliant comedy. Some will remember Winnenger as "Wash" the town drunk from DESTRY RIDES AGAIN. This one has it all, running the gammit from high comedy to classic tragic love.Whale went to great lengths to make a very faithful adaption of the original musical, casting many actors from the original stage play. The cinematograpy and sets are stunning. The songs themselves are also something pretty special.There will be much that sounds familiar in this. This is because of the fact that this was the first American Musical. The first to use song as a way to both propel the plot and dialogue and be an integral part of the story itself. Showboat is the birth of an art form. There are so many hooks in these songs that have been used countless times since, if you wonder where you heard them before, then this movie will answer that question. It begins here, with Showboat.
summary: James Whales "Show Boat"  a spectacular achievment.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Luckily, I am one of the few who owns this wonderful, early Hollywood Cinematic Gem, in the Criterion Edition that came out on LaserDisc in 1989. I thank my Lucky Stars every time I watch it!Inquiring Minds, INCLUDING MINE, want to know WHERE IS IT on DVD?WHY do we NOT have this Hollywood Masterpiece on DVD, since it has ALREADY been "mastered" digitally by Criterion, and transferring it to DVD should, certainly, be a SIMPLE matter, thus the Question, Again, WHERE IS IT?This grand old film is certainly one of the finest musical film productions that EVER came out of Hollywood, and being such an early one, it must, then, bespeak of those who produced and directed, and did all the other technical and design work, etc., involved to bring this all about.Of course, it was not the original film version...that came out in 1929, and was edited and censored, thus it is negated, and becomes a moot point, or film.And so it is that this, the 1936 version, is recognized as the "first"  and will be endeared to many because of this perception of the "first"...most people do not even realize there was a prior film of "Show Boat" before this one. When I refer to this one as "first" it is, again, because the original 1929 one is forgotten, or best forgotten.The later version of 1951, with Grayson/Keel, just does not hold up to this original film version of the great Kern/Hammerstein Musical.Of course, further, this first film version had many of the Original Broadway Cast in it, which, certainly, helped to add "authenticity" to it, if you will, since they had "lived" their parts previously on the stage.And, in general, the cast simply just WAS better all round than the later version from MGM in 1951. Also, for some reason, I find that black and white just "fits" this story SO much better....it just "tells" better in good old black and white than with all the Technicolor Goo-Gaa foisted onto it by the "masters", if you will, at MGM...they did not, after all, "know everything!" This is what I consider a "small" story...intimate, touching, and black and white and shades of gray just "fit" it well.If I had to pick only 5 film musicals to be able to keep forever, this would figure in, first, rightly, with Carousel, Oklahoma, The King and I, and Singing in the Rain....all others would have to fall by the wayside, including The Band Wagon, Seven Brides for Seven Brothers, The Unsinkable Molly Brown, An American in Paris, Funny Face, and My Fair Lady...all big favorites of mine, but those 5 must reign supreme!One last time, I ask, WHERE IS THIS? and WHY DO WE NOT HAVE IT for our enjoyment?When we look at all the "trash" that has been foisted onto us on DVD, it is all the more sad that we do not have films like this one, and, too, The African Queen....WHERE IS THAT, Also?Inquiring Minds Want to Know......
summary: OK, So WHERE is it? WHY do we NOT have it?

It's a gorgeous transfer, and if any of you out there want to see it come out on DVD, I'd suggest writing or e-mailing the fine people of Criterion to release it. I love the story and the music, and found a few scenes worthwile in the 1951 version, but ultimately it's unsatisfying...like watching the James Dean version of EAST OF EDEN after having read Steinbeck's novel or seeing the wonderful miniseries with Jane Seymour that was done for TV. reviewText: This is the best version of Show Boat in spite of it's politically/socially incorrect presentation of character and lyric. Still it does have Paul Robeson (who changed the lyrics of Old Man River in future performances), and that alone should be enough. Charlie Winninger gives a truly fabulous performance as Captain Andy and of course there is Irene Dunne reprising her Broadway role that lead her to Hollywood; there never has been a greater nor more talented beauty. There is a rare Helen Morgan sighting which may give the viewer an appreciation of what a star she was in her time. James Whale directs in fine fashion. The quality of the DVD is good in both picture and sound doing justice to the film and the performers. I wish that it cost a little less, but this is a keeper for fans of the show, the performers, or just fine film.
summary: This is Show Boat

reviewText: Jerome Kern's and Oscar Hammerstein's SHOWBOAT is a landmark Broadway musical.  It was brought to the screen in 1936 by Universal Studios with most of it's drama, joy, and heartbreak intact.  James Whale (BRIDE OF  FRANKENSTEIN, THE INVISIBLE MAN) might seem an odd choice for this project,  yet his direction hits the mark: realistic and gritty when it needs to be,  stylized and theatrical when it can afford to be.  The film is blessed with  a magnificent cast, most of whom had previously played their roles on  stage: Irene Dunne played Magnolia in the 1927 touring company, Allan Jones  appeared as Ravenal in summer stock, and Paul Robeson starred as Joe in the  1928 London production and then again in the 1932 Broadway revival.  Charles Winninger, Helen Morgan, and the underrated Sammy White starred in  the 1927 and 1932 Broadway productions and understand their characters  thoroughly.  White's eccentric dancing is hilarious and Morgan's turn as  the tragic Julie may well have you fighting back tears.  While some  favorite songs are missing, three were written specifically for the movie;  one of them,"I Have The Room Above Her," found it's way into the  recent Broadway revival directed by Harold Prince.  SHOWBOAT isn't  perfect: Hammerstein's screenplay unnecessarily alters the final section of  the story, and Irene Dunne's performance in blackface of "Gallivantin'  Around" might possibly offend some in this day and age.  But SHOWBOAT  has so much to delight and engage the viewer that these minor flaws can,  and should, be overlooked.  By the way, keep an eye open for Eddie  "Rochester" Anderson in the opening scenes.
summary: Excellent Adaptation of a Theatrical Landmark

reviewText: At long last I feel as if I have gotten to see this show the way it was meant to be shown, in glorious black and white but with most of the music intact from the original stage production. Having been disappointed in the 1952 version but not sure why, now I am sure. It tells only half the story. This version, with Irene Dunn as Magnolia, is as good as it gets. Alen Jones has a fine singing voice as Ravenal, the no-good gambler Magnolia marries. Based on the original novel by Edna Ferber, this version doesn't veer much from the oiriginal, but in the novel, Ravenal never comes back to Magnolia. The supporting cast of this film is as good as it gets as well. With Hattie McDaniel and Paul Robeson just for starters. McDaniel, is, of course, the Mammy of GWTW fame. We even hear McDaniel, who was a trained singer, sing, and her voice blends well with the Fish Gotta Swim number. Robeson, of course, gives powerful voice to the iconic song from this show, Old Man River. William Warfield almost matches it in the 1951 verson, but not quite. Too bad they didn't have stereophonic sound when this version was made. If you have to purchase only one version, be sure its the 1936 one. You'll be grateful you did.
summary: Much better than the 1951 version

reviewText: Take my word for it--this "Show Boat" leaves the 1951 version back at the dock. Irene Dunne is thoroughly engaging as Magnolia, the daughter of Cap'n Andy who runs the Cotton Blossom show boat on the Mississippi just after the Civil War. Dapper gentleman Gaylord (Alan Jones) joins the little troupe to escape from inquiries into his gambling debts, and wastes little time before launching into my favorite piece from the score, the duet "Only Make Believe" to describe his blossoming feelings for Magnolia. Things get shaken up when the stars of the troupe are discovered to have a misceganous marriage, a crime in that part of the Deep South. So Julie (Helen Morgan), Magnolia's role model and friend, must depart into the night, leaving the path clear for Magnolia and Gay to become the new stage (and off-stage) lovers on the show boat. Marriage soon follows, but Gay's gambling rears its head again, and much heartbreak is in store for Magnolia before fame and eventual happiness find her once more.While the plot of "Show Boat" is predictable, it shines as a musical with showstopping numbers and atmospheric stagings. The most famous song "Ol' Man River" is sung to great effect by Paul Robeson, and is filmed wonderfully with very inventive crane work for this early date. A rare treat is the original Julie, Helen Morgan, introducing "Can't Help Lovin' Dat Man" and "Bill", both songs about loving your man in spite of yourself. The staging of "Can't Help Lovin' Dat Man" features Irene Dunne doing a cakewalk, which would most likely appall today's more politically correct audiences, but draws a chuckle nonetheless for its improbableness. Even the period number "After the Ball" is given an authentic vaudeville treatment that transports the viewer back over a hundred years.Spend a lazy hour or two on the "Show Boat" and bask in this lovely Kern-Hammerstein score, the first true modern musical on Broadway.
summary: Can't Help Lovin' Dat Movie

reviewText: This film version of "Show Boat," while not perfect, is the best one available.  Not only does it follow the story more closely (except for the end) but it also preserves three performances by members of the  original Broadway cast -- Sammy White, Charles Winninger, and Helen Morgan.  White is very good, his frenetic dancing a highlight, and Winninger is a  real winner as Andy.  However, Morgan's performance is a revelation -- we  get a chance for once to sample a bit of musical theatre history  first-hand.  She is what Kern and Hammerstein originally intended, a frail,  touching, tender Julie, who also sings her songs in the original soprano  keys.  In addition to this, Irene Dunne as Magnolia is lovely (she took  over the role on Broadway from Norma Terris, the original Magnolia), and we  are truly lucky to have Paul Robeson's Joe, the original choice for the  role.  You can hardly get closer to authenticity than this cast, and the  entire production was supervised by Kern and Hammerstein themselves.  This  film is the one to own if you want the best "Show Boat."
summary: As close to the original as we'll get

reviewText: Although it is on tape, it is a T-120 tape (2 hour capacity) and is recorded at standard play, not extended play.Sound is mono, of course, and is VHS Hi-Fi.The video has NOT been encrypted using Macrovision. Video quality is good, considering that the source was probably a nitrate fine-grain element.For those who are new to "Show Boat", arguably the best of the earliest true musicals, this is a faithful adaptation of Edna Ferber's novel and, of course, of the earlier Ziegfeld musical, not the watered-down, Technicolor-enhanced version found in the 1951 remake.This 1936 version is itself a remake of the 1920s part-talkie, but the similarity stops there, as the 1936 version is a new, bold attempt at translating a stage-based musical to film.All except three of the original musical's numbers are faithfully put to film and sound. The three which were deleted are available on the very good EMI three-CD set (ISBN 0-77774-91082-8) which also includes the libretto. The three which were deleted were deleted for time, as the musical runs 3 hours and the 1936 film runs just under 2 hours.A new number, also by Kern and Hammerstein, and arranged by the show's original arranger, Robert Russell Bennett, provides a "blackface" number, "Gallivantin' Aroun'" which serves as a humorous transition from the teenage Magnolia to the adult Magnolia, the show's principal player. This new song, substantially rearranged by Bennett, also serves as the source music for numerous "bridges" which accompany the numerous montages which are used towards the very end of the film to signify the passage of many years' time. Rearranged in up-tempo or down-tempo as required to fit the montages. ("Blackface" was not used in the original production.) Victor Baravalle, the show's original conductor, serves as music director and conductor for this film as well.Alas, there is no DVD available for this version, but this film is certainly deserving of one.This film was added to the National Film Registry, in 1996.LATE NEWS!Warners has decided to release a restored version on DVD!The initial production run will be "manufactured" (pressed) DVDs.All subsequent production runs are expected to be "DVD on Demand" (recorded) DVDs.
summary: Complete Version of the Classic 1936 Version

reviewText: SHOW BOAT was one of the most original musicals of the 1930s and was, indeed, years ahead of its time.  One has to compare it with all of the other movie musicals of its decade to realize just how unusual it was.  Most other musicals of the decade were focused on the musical theater (think of all those Busby Berkeley musicals) or contained a heavy element of romantic comedy.  There is certainly some of both of those elements in SHOW BOAT, but it completely exploded the boundaries that restricted the other films.  There is an epic quality to SHOW BOAT that is completely missing in the other films, as well as a sense of Americana.Virtually no one who sees this and the later MGM version will prefer the latter.  This black and white version has a visual dynamism and energy completely lacking in the MGM color one.  The editing is crisp and often startling, and the screen often shifts from one performer's face to another when one least anticipates it.  The vitality the film emits carries the viewer along with it, something that can hardly be said of the later version.  I even prefer the performances of the famous numbers, not least because MGM seemed determine to make each one more of a big performance number, which oddly had the effect of making them seem less personal and more remote.  Even the greatest performance in the 1951 version, that of the great William Warfield as Joe, is surpassed by Paul Robeson's performance, more on the strength of his personality than his singing ability (Warfield was one of the truly great lieder singers of the past half century, but Robeson was both a great singer and a great actor).The cast of the 1936 film also far surpasses that of the 1951 one.  Irene Dunne was a much better actress than Kathryn Grayson and was, therefore, able to imbue Magnolia Hawks with far more depth.  Though Allan Jones and Howard Keel are comparable, in every instance I would take the performer from the 1936 version over the later one.  It is with a sense almost of regret that one watches Paul Robeson in this one.  They added the song "Ah Still Suits Me" to the film to give Robeson a larger role, but even so one wishes that his screen time had been doubled.  Robeson was, by any standard, one of the most amazing Americans of the 20th century, and is perhaps less well known than he deserves to be by the fact that he seemed to be capable of doing everything well.  His resume seems impossible.  He was Phi Beta Cappa valedictorian in his class at Rutgers where he was also an All American football player, played professional football while attending Columbia Law School, able to speak a couple of dozen languages, and excelled as an actor (both stage and screen), a singer, as an author, and as a political activist.  The part of Joe was written specifically for him, as was "Old Man River," though his schedule prevented him from being in the original production.  Although he recently appeared on a U.S. stamp, he should be remembered even more than he is.  Partly because of his politics (he refused to cooperate with the Un-American Activities Committee) and partly because he refused to be in films in demeaning roles, he appeared in very few films.James Whale is better known today than he was a few years ago, largely because of the film GODS AND MONSTERS, in which Ian McKellan portrayed him in his final days.  The truth is that Whale was one of the great directors of the first decade of sound film, and his disappearance from the directing corps in Hollywood only a few years following SHOW BOAT is a tragedy.  He was especially innovative in his use of the more technologically advanced and mobile cameras developed early in the 1930s, and the number of first-rate films was substantial.  Most know of FRANKENSTEIN, THE INVISIBLE MAN, and BRIDE OF FRANKENSTEIN, but he also directed such stellar films as WATERLOO BRIDGE, JOURNEY'S END, and the remarkable THE OLD DARK HOUSE.  Like Robeson, Whale, though known, deserves even more acclaim than has been given him.This truly is one of the great classics of the American movie musical, and a film that anyone who loves movies should know.  It has a great score, a great visual style, fine performances, and a magnificent cast.  Now all it needs is the appropriate DVD treatment.
summary: One of the most remarkable musicals of the 1930s

reviewText: I'm grateful now that I saw the Keel-Grayson version from the 1950sfirst.  Had I seen it after the 1936 version, I'm not sure if I couldhave handled the letdown.  Remarkably, the recent film based on thelife of James Whale, director of the original"Frankenstein," made little mention of this film, oneHollywood's historic achievements.  This film has charm, pacing, ablend of cinematic and musical values, and above all a supremeperformance by one of Hollywood's underrated, virtuosic actresses,Irene Dunne.  Her version of "Can't Help Loving the Man"came as a revelation, capturing all of the bluesy, folksy charm of thetune and setting it in the African-American context Kern had in mind.Those viewers who are so indoctrinated by "politicalcorrectness" as to experience knee-jerk reactions to any"white" intepretations of the pain/joy of black culture willsimply have to remain content in their segregated righteousness.  Themusical is about the integration of the races, and Dunne's"shuffle dance" celebrates her innocent joy over blacktraditions and her assimilation of them, to the approval of thosecharacters who assumed such music and dance was off-limits to whitefolk. The musical is also about the assimilation of musical styles,and Dunne's rendition of "You Are Love" is a lovelyexpression of Kern's operatic, European roots.  The only majordisappointment in this fast-paced film is the omission of thestandard, "Why Do I Love You"?
summary: Miraculous movie.

reviewText: This middle version of SHOW BOAT is the most authentic. Although the 1951 M-G-M version is mighty pretty to look at in its ravishing Technicolor, this version is much truer to what Edna Ferber had in mind. Without going into great detail about the story, I'll just say that the film is about the life and loves of the personnel on an old-time Mississippi showboat. Charles Winninger is terrific as Captain Andy (he played the role on Broadway). The little-seen-in-movies Helen Morgan played her role of Julie on the stage as well, and her performance is unforgettable: a rare chance to watch a legendary artist at work: she would die in obscurity via alcoholism in 1941. Irene Dunne is fine as Magnolia, few movie-goers know that she was a professional singer as well as a fine dramatic actress and a wonderful Screwball comedienne. Paul Robeson is magnetic when he sings that classic paean to the the Mississippi river, Ol' MAN RIVER. Helen Westley and Hattie McDaniel shine in their supporting roles as Parthy Hawks and Queenie Joe's wife respectively. In fact, the cast is full of diverse character actors: Barbara Pepper (Doris Ziffle on GREEN ACRES), Elspeth Dudgeon (the ancient patriarch in THE OLD DARK HOUSE), Flora Finch (she was a silent star circa 1915 in comedy shorts called "Bunnyfinches" with her co-star John Bunny) Marilyn Harris (whom Frankenstein's monster threw into the lake), Harry Barris (one of the original Rhythm Boys with Bing Crosby & brother of blues singer Mildred Bailey), Helen Jerome Eddy (Annie Alden in Mae West's KLONDIKE ANNIE). The story had been filmed less successfully priorly in 1929 with the now-forgotten Laura LaPlante as Magnolia. The acting kudos went to the heroin-addicted Alma Reubens as Julie; Reubens would die in an insane asylum at the age of 33.
summary: DEFINITIVE FILM VERSION.

reviewText: This film version of this story is the definitive version.  Please disregard the horrid 1951 re-make of this classic.  The more sensitive and politically correct will be offended by the minstrel shows that are part of the entertainment on the showboat, but this is really part of the history of entertainment.  Minstrel shows were very popular at the time, and enjoyed by both black and white audiences.  The portrayal of the black characters in this film, and the lampooning of them in the minstrel show sections, to me is very revealing of the ignorance of white people, if they indeed actually thought that this is what African-Americans were really like.  Also, this was the first film to show black characters in serious roles that explored the problems of race and discrimination.  Paul Robeson's stunning rendition of "Ol' Man River" stops the show, and brings home the brutality of slavery in a very poignant and accessible way.  But I am spending an inordinate amount of time on a relatively small portion of the film; because that is the only reason I can find that this great old movie has been abandoned.  Fantastic performances by Irene Dunne, Helen Morgan, Hattie McDaniel, and Helen Westley make this a cinematic showpiece, and a must-see.  Truly a gem of film history.
summary: An excellent film - a must see for any lover of old movies!
Title: N/A

reviewText: “Show Boat” is the 1936 version of the Jerome Kern/Oscar Hammerstein II musical based on Edna Ferber’s novel. Directed by James Whale, the movie stars Irene Dunne as Magnolia, Allan Jones as dashing riverboat gambler Gaylord Ravenal, Helen Morgan as Julie, Paul Robeson as Joe, and Hattie McDaniel (“Gone With the Wind”) as Queenie.The songs are beautifully performed by the principals. Standouts are Robeson’s rendition of “Ol’ Man River;” “Can’t Help Lovin’ That Man,” in which Julie amusingly teaches Magnolia to shuffle; and Julie’s torch song, “Bill,” sung when she is in the depths of alcoholic depression. Three new songs — “I Have the Room Above Her,” “I Still Suits Me,” and “Gallivantin' Around” — were written for this film.Whale, best known as the director of “Frankenstein” and “Bride of Frankenstein,” does a splendid job opening up the stage play, taking full advantage of the nearly limitless parameters of cinema. The movie never looks stage-bound because of Whale’s imaginative camera placement and expert editing.There are no bonus features on the DVD-only release.
summary: Great Score, Great Cast in Best Screen Version of a Classic

reviewText: Darker and a lot less sentimentalized than MGM's 1951 remake, but no less entertaining, this 1936 film version of the grandaddy of modern American musicals is the best representation of the stage show yet to be seen on film.  Although many songs and "book scenes" had to be cut, and a few new songs were written especially for the film, (Most of which are just as good, anyway) the ESSENCE of the Broadway production is perfectly conveyed.  This is probably because Oscar Hammerstein was (thankfully) allowed to adapt his original libretto to the screen, and composer Jerome Kern oversaw all musical aspects of the production.  (The film orchestrations are simply "augmented" versions of Robert Russell Bennett's unmatched originals)  And what is even better, and amazing considering how this is so often not the case in film musicals, just about every actor in this film acted in a stage production of the show beforehand.  Her performance as Magnolia in the first touring company was what got Irene Dunne a Hollywood contract, and she doesn't dissapoint here; although she is perhaps too old for the early scenes when her character is supposed to be a 17-year-old, and her "Can't Help Lovin' Dat Man" shuffle and blackface number (which was written for the film) are painful reminders of another, less racially sensitive time today, she nevertheless is very effective as an actress, and has a very pleasing operetic soprano to boot.  Allan Jones is a fine Ravenal, recreating a role he'd played in St. Louis in 1934, and Hattie McDaniel steals all her scenes as Queenie, whom she'd played in a 1933 West Coast production.  Thankfuly, we also get Helen Morgan and CHarles Winninger recreating their original Broadway roles as Julie and Cap'n Andy.  While her soprano voice may sound strange compared to the "huskier"-voiced Julies normally heard today, and while those jusky voices may better convey Julie's secret African-American roots, torch singer Morgan's sad, "lost soul" quailty has never been equalled in the part, and her heartbreaking "Bill" is still the definitive version.  Winninger is in fine form, and his "Parson's Bride" shtick is a comic showstopper.  And to top it all off, we have Paul Robeson recreating his London performance as Joe, a role originally planned for him, delivering his own definitive version of "Ol' Man River."  Director James Whale, best known for "Frankenstein," does not shy away from presenting a realistic and unsentimental view of the lives of the show boat folks and certainly keeps things moving, but does not attempt too much to put his own stamp on the material, aside from a different ending than what occurs in most stage productions.  The songs of the glroious Kern-Hammerstein score that remain, and all the new ones added in, (Except the blackface number) are all very well-performed; it is a shame that they had to delete the beautiful opening verses to "You Are Love," because without them the song just becomes another operetta love song with both leads singing unintelligle lyrics at the top of their lungs, but other than that, the songs from the show are largely untouched, which is just fine.  The strongest and most moving film record of a classic of musical theatre, and a darn good film in its own right.
summary: The best film representation of the stage show +agreat film!
